The Spirit of Sweetwater by Hamlin Garland
This recording is by Roger Melin

9.text:
THE MYSTERY OF MOUNTAINS
As the sun sinks

14.text:
And the cañons deepening in color
Add mystery to silence

18.text:
Then the lone traveller lying out-stretched
Beneath the silent pines on some high range

25.text:
Watches and listens in ecstasy of fear
And timorous admiration.

31.text:
In the roar of the stream he catches
The reminiscent echo of colossal cataracts;

37.text:
In the cry of the cliff-bird
He thinks he hears the eagle's scream

41.text:
Or yowl of far-off mountain-lion;
In the fall of a loose rock

47.text:
He fancies the menacing footfall of the grizzly
bear;

52.text:
And in the black deeps of the lower cañon
His dreaming eyes detect once more

57.text:
Prodigious lines of buffalo crawling snake-wise
Athwart the stream,

62.text:
Or files of Indian warriors
Winding downward to the distant plain,

67.text:
Where camp-fires gleam like stars.
Part I

73.text:
The Spirit of Sweetwater
CHAPTER I

79.text:
One spring day a young man of good mental
furnishing and very slender purse walked over

86.text:
the shoulder of Mount Mogallon and down the
trail to Gold Creek. He walked because the

92.text:
stage fare seemed too high.
Two years and four months later he was pointed

98.text:
out to strangers by the people of Sweetwater
Springs. "That is Richard Clement, the sole

105.text:
owner of 'The Witch,' a mine valued at three
millions of dollars." This in itself was truly

113.text:
an epic.
Sweetwater Springs was a village in a cañon,

119.text:
out of which rose two wonderful springs of
water whose virtues were known throughout

124.text:
the land. The village was wedged in the cañon
which ran to the mighty breast of Mogallon

132.text:
like a fold in a king's robe.
The village and its life centered around the

137.text:
pavilion which roofed the spring, and Clement
spent his evenings there in order to see the

143.text:
people, at least, as they joyously thronged
about the music-stand and sipped the beautiful

149.text:
water which the Utes long, long ago called
"sweet water," and visited with reverence

156.text:
and hope of returning health.
Since the coming of his great wealth Clement

162.text:
had not allowed himself a day's vacation,
and he had grown ten years older in that time.

169.text:
There were untimely signs of age in his hair
and in the troubled lines of his face. He

176.text:
was a young man, but he looked a strong and
stern and careworn man to those whose attention

182.text:
was called to him. He was a conscientious
man, and the possession of great wealth was

189.text:
not without its gravities.
For the first time he felt it safe to leave

194.text:
his mine in other hands. He had a longing
to mix with his kind once more, and in his

201.text:
heart was the secret hope that somewhere among
the women of the Springs he might find a girl

207.text:
to take to wife. He arranged his vacation
for July, not because it was ever hot at the

214.text:
Creek, but because he knew the Springs swarmed
at that time with girls from the States. It

220.text:
would have troubled him had any one put these
ideas into words and accused him of really

225.text:
seeking a bride.
He was a self-unconscious man naturally, and

231.text:
he hardly realized yet how widely his name
had gone as the possessor of millions. He

237.text:
supposed himself an unnoticed atom as he stood
at the spring on the second night of his stay

243.text:
in the village. Of a certainty many did not
know him, but they saw him, for he was a striking

250.text:
figure—a handsome figure—though that had
never concerned him. He was, in fact, feeling

257.text:
his own insignificance.
He was standing there in shadow looking out

263.text:
somberly upon the streams of people as they
came to take their evening draught at the

268.text:
wonderful water of the effervescing spring.
The sun had gone behind the high peaks to

275.text:
the west, and a delicious, dry coolness was
in the cañon.

280.text:
It seemed to Clement to be a very fashionable
and leisurely throng—so long had he been

286.text:
absent from people either modish or easeful.
He felt himself to be hopelessly outside all

293.text:
this youth and brilliancy and merriment, and
he looked upon it all with a certain wistfulness.

300.text:
He perceived at length that the strollers
were not all of the same conditions. There

305.text:
were rough, brown cow-boys from La Junta and
Cajon, and miners in rough dress down from

313.text:
the gulches for a night, but mainly the promenaders
appealed to him with elegance of dress and

319.text:
manner.
Many of the ladies came without hats, which

324.text:
added to the charm of their eyes and hair.
Some of them looked twice at the tall man

330.text:
with the big mustache and broad hat, who seemed
to be watching for some tardy friend.

337.text:
As he studied them his memory freshened and
he came to understand them better. He analyzed

343.text:
them into familiar types. This was a banker
and his wife from some small town—the wife

351.text:
fussy and consequential, the husband coldly
dignified. This group was composed of a doctor

359.text:
and his daughters. Behind them came a merchant
from some Nebraska town—he rough of exterior,

367.text:
his children dainty of dress and very pretty.
Occasionally a group of college-bred girls

374.text:
came up without escort—alert, self-helpful
and serene. They saw Clement at once, and

382.text:
studied him carefully as they drank their
beauty cup at the circular bench before the

387.text:
spring. All good-looking men had interest
to them.

392.text:
All classes came, a varied stream, yet they
were Western, and of the well-to-do condition

399.text:
for the larger part.
The deft boy swung the glasses of water on

404.text:
his tripartite dipper with ceaseless splash
and clink. There was a pleasant murmur of

411.text:
talk in which an Eastern listener would have
heard the "r" sound well-defined. There were

417.text:
many couples seated about the pavilion on
the benches and railings. It was all busy

424.text:
yet tranquil. Each loiterer had fed, had taken
his draught of healing water—and this was

431.text:
the hour of pleasant gossip and repose. Clement
fell at last to analyzing the action of the

439.text:
boy who supplied the water at the pool. He
slammed the glasses into the pool, and set

446.text:
them on the bench with a click as regular
as a pump. Occasionally, however, he was indifferent.

454.text:
With some of his customers he handled the
glasses as if they contained nectar, thus

459.text:
indicating his generous patrons. Once he stopped
and dipped the glass into the pool with his

466.text:
own hand—a doubtful action—and extended
it with a bow to a young lady who said "thank

472.text:
you" so sweetly that he blushed and stammered
in reply.

478.text:
All this fixed Clement's attention, and as
the young girl lifted the glass in her slim

484.text:
hand he wondered how she had escaped his notice
for a single moment. A woman at his side said

492.text:
sighfully, "There is that consumptive girl
again, she hasn't long to stay." She was as

500.text:
pale, as fragile, and as lovely as the mountain
columbine. Her face was thin, and her head

509.text:
shapely, but her eyes! They burned like rarest
topaz—deep, dark and sad. Clement shivered

519.text:
as he felt them fixed upon him, and yet he
could not turn away as he should have done.

526.text:
He gazed at her with a sudden feeling which
was not awe, nor compassion, nor love, but

533.text:
was all of these. He felt in his soul the
subtlest sadness in all the world—the sadness

540.text:
of a strong man who looks upon a beautiful
young girl who is dying.

547.text:
Extremest languor was in every movement. She
was dressed in dark, soft garments—very

555.text:
simple and graceful in effect, and her bearing
was that of one accustomed to willing service

560.text:
from others. Her smile was as sad as her eyes
which had in them the death-shadow.

569.text:
Clement's action, the unwavering self-forgetful
intentness of his look, arrested her attention,

576.text:
and she returned his gaze for an instant,
and then turned away and took the arm of an

582.text:
elderly gentleman who stood beside her. She
moved slowly, as an invalid walks when for

589.text:
the first time she is permitted a short walk
in the outdoor air, leaning heavily on her

594.text:
companion.
The big miner roused himself and stood straight

599.text:
and tall, hesitating whether to follow or
not—a sudden singular pain in his heart,

606.text:
as if he were losing something very close
to his life.

611.text:
He obeyed the impulse to follow, and moved
down the path, just out of reach of observation,

618.text:
he fancied. As he made way through the crowd
he grew aware again of his heavy limbs, of

625.text:
his great height, of his swinging, useless
hands. It had been so long since he had mingled

633.text:
with a holiday company, he appeared as self-conscious
as a boy.

639.text:
Once the fair invalid turned and looked back,
but she was too far away for him to discern

644.text:
the expression of her face. He was not possessed
of self-esteem enough to believe she had turned

651.text:
to look for him.
He followed them in their slow pace till they

656.text:
turned in at the doorway of the principal
hotel of the village. They entered at the

662.text:
ladies' door while he kept on to the main
entrance and rotunda. There was no elevator

668.text:
in the house, and the invalid paused a moment
before attempting the stairway. It was pitiful

675.text:
to see her effort to make light of it all
to her companion, who was quite evidently

680.text:
her father. She smiled at him even while she
pressed one slim hand against her bosom.

688.text:
Clement longed to take her in his arms and
carry her up the stairway—it seemed the

693.text:
thing most worth doing in all the world—but
he could only lean against the desk and see

699.text:
them go slowly stair by stair out of sight.
"Who are they?" he asked of the clerk whom

707.text:
he detected also watching them with almost
the same breathless interest.

712.text:
"Chicago merchant, G. B. Ross. That's his
daughter. She's pretty far gone—consumption,

721.text:
I reckon. It looks tough to see a girl like
that go off. You'd think now——"

729.text:
Clement did not remain to hear the clerk moralize
further; he went immediately to his own hotel,

736.text:
paid his bill, and ordered his baggage sent
to the other house. He wondered at himself

742.text:
for this overpowering interest in a sick girl,
and at his plan to see her again.

750.text:
He reasoned that he would be able to see her
at breakfast time, provided she came down

754.text:
to breakfast, and provided he hit upon the
same hour of eating. He began to calculate

761.text:
upon the probable hour when she would come
down. It was astounding how completely she

768.text:
occupied his thought already.
He struck off up the cañon where no sound

775.text:
was, other than the roar of the wild little
stream which seemed to lift its voice in wilder

781.text:
clamor as the night fell. Its presence helped
him to think out his situation. He had grown

789.text:
self-analytical during his life in the camp,
where he was alone so far as his finer feelings

795.text:
were concerned, and he had come to believe
in many strange things which he said nothing

800.text:
about to any friend he had.
He had come to believe in fate and also in

807.text:
intuition. A powerful impulse to do he counted
higher than reason. That is to say, if he

815.text:
had a powerful impulse to run a shaft in a
certain direction he would so act, no matter

821.text:
if his reason declared dead against it. The
hidden and uncontrollable processes of his

829.text:
mind had given him the secret of "The Witch's"
gold, had led him right in his shafting and

836.text:
in his selection of friends and assistants—and
had made him a millionaire at thirty-seven

842.text:
years of age. He was prone to over-value the
intuitional side of his nature, probably—an

850.text:
error common among practical men.
Fate was, with him, luck raised to a higher

858.text:
power. What was to be would be; the unexpected
happened; the expected, hoped for, labored

867.text:
for, did not always happen. All around him
men stumbled upon mines, while other men,

875.text:
more skilful, more observant, failed. The
luck was against them.

881.text:
It was quite in harmony with his nature that
he should be absorbed in the singular and

886.text:
powerful impulse he had to seek an acquaintance
with that poor dying girl.

893.text:
Dying! At that word he rebelled. God would
not take so beautiful a creature away from

901.text:
earth; men needed her to teach them gentleness
and submission. More than this, he had an

908.text:
almost uncontrollable impulse to go to her,
and putting aside doctors say to her:

915.text:
"I am the one to heal you."
He had never had an impulse to heal before,

921.text:
but the fact that it was unaccountable and
powerful and definite, fitted in with his

927.text:
successes. He gave it careful thought. It
must mean something because it had never come

935.text:
to him before, and because it rose out of
the mysterious depths of his brain.

941.text:
She must not die! The wind, the mountains,
the clear air, the good, sweet water, the

950.text:
fragrant pines, the splendid sun—these things
must help her. "And I, perhaps I, too, can

959.text:
help her?"
Back in the glare of the hotel rotunda, with

964.text:
its rows of bored men sitting stolidly smoking,
idly talking, his impulse and his resolution

972.text:
seemed very unmanly and preposterous. It is
so easy to lose faith in the elemental in

979.text:
the midst of the superficial and ephemeral
of daily habit.

984.text:
CHAPTER II
Clement was an early riser, and, notwithstanding

990.text:
his restless night, was astir at six. The
whole world had changed for him. It was no

998.text:
longer a question of ore and amalgams, it
was a question of when he should see again

1004.text:
that sad, slender woman with the hopeless
smile.

1009.text:
He had now a great fear that she would not
be able to come down to breakfast at all,

1014.text:
but as her coming was his only hope of seeing
her he clung to it. Eight o'clock seemed to

1021.text:
him to be the latest hour that any one not
absolutely bedridden would think of breakfasting,

1027.text:
and at four minutes past the hour he entered
the dining-room.

1032.text:
The negro waiter tried to seat him near the
door, but he pushed on down the hall toward

1038.text:
a little group near one of the sunny windows,
which he took to be the sick girl and her

1043.text:
father, and so it proved.
His seat at a table next to theirs brought

1049.text:
her profile between him and the window, and
the light around her head seemed to glorify

1055.text:
her till she shone like a figure in a church
window. She seemed not concerned with earth.

1063.text:
He was more deeply moved than ever before
in his life, but he concealed it—the only

1069.text:
sign of emotion was in the tremor of his hands.
He studied the sick girl as closely as he

1076.text:
could without seeming to stare. She was even
more lovely than he had thought. His eyes,

1084.text:
accustomed only to rough women, found in her
beauty that which was flower-like, seraphic.

1092.text:
Her face was very thin, and her neck too slender
to uphold the heavy masses of her brown hair.

1100.text:
Her hands were only less expressive of suffering
than her face. The father was as bluff and

1107.text:
portly and irascible as she was patient and
gentle. He bullied the waiter because he did

1114.text:
not know how else to express his anxiety.
"Waiter, this steak is burned—it's hard

1121.text:
as sole leather. Take it back and bring me——"
"Please don't, father; the trouble is with

1129.text:
me. I have no desire for food." She smiled
at the waiter so sweetly that he nodded as

1137.text:
if to say, "I don't mind him, miss."
The father turned his attention to the country.

1145.text:
"Yes, there is another fraud. I was told it
would help your appetite, and here you are

1152.text:
with less than when you left Hot Springs.
If I'd had my way——"

1158.text:
She laid a hand on his arm, and when he turned
toward her his eyes were dim with tears. He

1166.text:
blew his nose and coughed, and looked away
after the manner of men, and suffered in silence.

1174.text:
Once she turned and looked at Clement, and
her eyes had a mystical, impersonal look,

1180.text:
as though she saw him afar off, not as an
individual but as a type of some admirable

1187.text:
elemental creature. He could not fathom her
attitude toward him, but he thought he saw

1194.text:
in her every action the expression of a soul
that had relinquished its hold on things of

1200.text:
the earth. Her desire to live was no longer
personal. She did all that she did for her

1208.text:
father and her friends wholly to please them.
The desire to aid her came upon Clement again—so

1215.text:
powerful it carried with it an unwavering
belief that he could help her.

1221.text:
What was his newly-acquired wealth good for
if he could not aid her? Wealth? Yes—his

1228.text:
blood! He looked at his great brown hand and
at his big veins full of blood. Why should

1236.text:
she die when he had so much life?
Meanwhile his common sense had not entirely

1243.text:
fled him. He perceived that they were not
poor, and he reflected that they had probably

1249.text:
tried all climates and all the resources of
medical science; also that the father had

1256.text:
quite as much red blood in his veins as any
other man; and these considerations gave him

1263.text:
thought as he watched them rise and go out
upon the little veranda.

1269.text:
Clement was not a markedly humble person under
ordinary conditions. He had a fashion of pushing

1275.text:
rather heedlessly straight to his purpose—which
now was to speak to her, to meet her face

1282.text:
to face, to touch her hand and to offer his
aid. Naturally he sought the father's acquaintance

1290.text:
first. This was not difficult, for the waiters
in the dining-room had been pointing him out

1296.text:
to the guests as "Mr. Clement, the meyonaire
minah." The newspaper correspondents had made

1303.text:
his name a familiar one to the whole United
States as "one of the sudden multi-millionaires

1309.text:
of Gold Creek."
The porter had "passed the word" to the head

1314.text:
waiter, and the head waiter had whispered
it to one or two others. It was almost as

1320.text:
exciting as having a Presidential candidate
enter the room. Clement was too new in his

1327.text:
riches, however, to realize the extent of
all this bustle about him.

1332.text:
When he rose to go one waiter removed his
chair, another helped him lay his napkin down,

1339.text:
a third brushed his coat, and the head usher
kindly showed him where the door opened into

1345.text:
the hallway. It was wonderful to Clement,
but he laid it to the management of the hotel.

1353.text:
There were limits to his insanity, and he
did not follow the girl out on the veranda,

1359.text:
but when Mr. Ross came down a few minutes
later to get a cigar Clement plucked the proprietor

1365.text:
of the hotel by the arm.
"Introduce me to Mr. Ross, won't you?"

1371.text:
The landlord beamed. "Certainly, Mr. Clement."
He took Mr. Ross by the lapel familiarly.

1380.text:
"Ah, good-morning, Mr. Ross. Mr. Ross, let
me introduce my friend, Mr. Clement; Mr. Clement

1389.text:
you may have heard of as the owner of 'The
Witch' and the 'Old Wisconse.'"

1395.text:
Mr. Ross shook hands. He was not exactly uncivil,
but he was cool—very cool. "I have heard

1404.text:
of Mr. Clement," he said. He softened a little
as he got a good look at the powerful, clear-eyed

1412.text:
young fellow.
The landlord expanded like one who has accomplished

1417.text:
a good deed. "I thought so, I thought so.
Mr. Clement, let me say, is a square business

1425.text:
man. Whatever he offers you is worth the price!"
He winked at Clement as he turned away.

1435.text:
Clement began, "I beg your pardon, Mr. Ross,
for taking this liberty, but I wanted to know

1441.text:
you and took the first chance that offered.
I have no mine to sell—I want to know you—that's

1448.text:
all. I wanted to meet somebody outside the
mining interest. I saw you and your daughter

1455.text:
at the pavilion last night. She seems to be
not—very strong." He hesitated in his attempt

1464.text:
to describe his impression of her.
The father's theme was touched upon now. "No,

1472.text:
poor girl, she is in bad condition, but I
think she's better. The air seems not to have

1479.text:
made her worse, at any rate. I haven't much
faith in climate, but I believe she has improved

1486.text:
since we left Kansas City and began to rise."
He had a marvelous listener in Clement, and

1493.text:
they consumed three cigars apiece while he
told of the doctors he had tried and of the

1499.text:
different kinds of air and water they had
sought.

1503.text:
His eyes were wet and his voice was tremulous.
"The fact is, Mr. Clement, she don't seem

1510.text:
to care about living—that's what scares
me. She's just as sweet and lovely as an angel.

1518.text:
She responds to any suggestion, 'Very well,
papa,' but I can see she does it for me. She

1526.text:
herself has lost all hope. It ain't even that—she
has lost care about it. She is indifferent.

1534.text:
She is going away from me just because I can't
rouse her——"

1539.text:
He frankly broke down and stopped, and Clement
felt his throat swell too tight for speech

1545.text:
at the moment.
They sat for a time in silence; at last Clement

1551.text:
said:
"Mr. Ross, you don't know me except as a lucky

1556.text:
man—but I have a favor to ask: it is to
meet your daughter."

1562.text:
There was something very winning in the young
man's voice and manner, and Mr. Ross could

1567.text:
see no objection to it, and it might interest
Ellice to meet this man who had stumbled upon

1573.text:
a gold mine. "Very well, suppose we go up
now," he said, almost without hesitation.

1582.text:
The girl was alone, seated in an easy-chair
in the sun—her head only in shadow. The

1590.text:
father spoke in a low and very tender voice,
"Ellice, I want to present Mr. Clement. Mr.

1599.text:
Clement, my daughter Ellice."
The impossible had come to pass! As Clement

1606.text:
bent down and took her hand and looked into
her eyes his heart seemed to stop death-still

1612.text:
for a few seconds—then something new and
inexplicable took possession of him, and he

1618.text:
stood before her calm and clear-eyed. "Don't
move," he commanded, "I will draw a chair

1626.text:
near you."
Mr. Ross said they had been having a long

1630.text:
talk, and she listened, smiling the while
that hopeless smile. Then the father rose

1638.text:
and said: "Where is Aunt Sarah? I want to
go down to the telegraph office."

1645.text:
The girl spoke in the quiet, tranquil voice
of one to whom such things have no importance.

1651.text:
"I don't know, papa. A moment ago she was
saying something to me, and now she is gone.

1658.text:
That is all I know. Never mind; she'll be
here in a moment."

1664.text:
"I'll be back in ten minutes."
"I am all right, papa. If I need anything

1671.text:
Mr. Clement can call Aunt."
There was a pause after Mr. Ross went. Then

1678.text:
she added in the same gentle, emotionless
way: "Poor papa! He is a martyr to me. He

1686.text:
thinks he must sit by me always. I think he
fears I may die while he is gone."

1694.text:
Clement leaned forward till his eyes were
on a level with those of the girl, and his

1699.text:
voice was very calm and penetrating as he
said:

1703.text:
"What can I do for you, Miss Ross? I have
the profoundest conviction that I can do you

1708.text:
good."
A startled look came into the big brown eyes.

1714.text:
She looked at him as a babe might, striving
to comprehend.

1720.text:
He went on, "Here I am a millionaire, a strong
young man—what can I do for you?"

1727.text:
"I think I understand you," she said slowly.
"It's very good of you, but you can do nothing."

1736.text:
"It is impossible," he broke forth in answer,
and his voice gave her a perceptible shock.

1744.text:
"There must be something I can do. If it will
help you there is my arm—its blood is yours."

1753.text:
He stammered a little. "It isn't right that
one so young and beautiful should die. We

1759.text:
won't let you die. There must be something
I can do. This wind and sun—and the good

1766.text:
water will work with us to do you good."
His voice moved her, and she smiled with the

1774.text:
tears on her lashes. "It does me good just
to look at you. You are so big and brown.

1782.text:
I saw you at the spring last night. Perhaps
I have come at last——" She coughed—a

1789.text:
weak, flat sound which made him shudder.
She tried to reassure him. "Really, I have

1797.text:
coughed less than at any time during the last
five months."

1803.text:
He faced her again. "Miss Ross, I felt last
night a sudden desire to help you. I believed

1811.text:
I had the power to help you—I don't know
why—I'm not a healer." He smiled for the

1817.text:
first time. "But I felt perfectly sure I could
do you good. I feel that way now. I never

1826.text:
had such a feeling toward any person before.
It is just as strange to me as it is to you."

1834.text:
She was looking at him now with musing eyes.
"That is the curious part of it," she said.

1841.text:
"It doesn't seem strange at all. It seems
as if I had been wanting to hear your voice—as

1848.text:
if I had known of you all my life——" She
tried to suppress her coughing, and he was

1854.text:
in agony during the paroxysm. The nurse came
hurrying out, and while he waited at one side

1862.text:
Clement felt that if he could have taken her
by the hands he could have prevented it. It

1867.text:
was a singular conviction, but it was most
definite, and had a peculiar air of actuality.

1875.text:
When she lay quiet he approached again and
said: "I'll go now. I must not tire you. But

1883.text:
remember, I'm going to come and see you, and
I'm going to do you good. Every time I see

1888.text:
you I am going to will to you some of my vitality—my
love of life. For I love life—it is beautiful

1898.text:
to live."
She gave him her hand, and he bowed and left

1903.text:
her.
She lay quietly after he went away and smiled,

1908.text:
a little, wan smile, which made her pallor
the more pitiful. It was all so romantic and

1916.text:
wonderful—this big man's coming. He was
so unspoiled and so direct of manner. She

1924.text:
had the hope he would come again, and it seemed
not impossible that he might help her, his

1930.text:
voice was so stirring and his hands so big
and strong.

1935.text:
Yet she was beyond the reach of even the conjectures
of passion. She had come to a certain exterior

1941.text:
resignation to her fate. The world had lost
its poignant interest—it was now a pageant

1949.text:
upon which she was looking for the last time,
yet she was too tired, too indifferent to

1956.text:
lift her hand to stay it in its course even
had it been within her power.

1962.text:
At times, however, she rebelled at her fate.
There were hours, even yet, when she lay alone

1970.text:
in her bed hearing her father's regular stertorous
breathing till a great wave of longing to

1976.text:
live swept upon her, and she was forced to
turn her face to her pillow to stifle her

1982.text:
mingled coughing and sobbing.
"Oh, Father, let me live! I want to live like

1988.text:
other women. Oh, dear Father, grant me a little
life!"

1994.text:
These waves of passionate rebellion left her
weaker, sadder, more indifferent than ever,

2001.text:
and as coldly pallid almost as if death had
already claimed her.

2007.text:
On the night following Clement's talk with
her she fell asleep while musing upon one

2013.text:
mind's influence upon another. Perhaps if
she could only believe she might be helped;

2020.text:
perhaps he was sent to help her. It had been
long since such a personality had stood before

2026.text:
her—indeed, no such man had ever touched
her hand or looked into her eyes.

2033.text:
He came down out of the mountain heights with
the elemental vigor of wind and sun and soil

2039.text:
about him like an aura. A man of great natural
refinement, he had grown strong and simple

2047.text:
and masterful in his close contact with Nature.
The clay that might have brutalized another

2054.text:
nature had made him a mystic.
There was something mysterious in his eyes,

2059.text:
in the clasp of his hand. The world was all
inexplicable to her anyhow. Perhaps God had

2067.text:
sent him to help her just as He sends healing
water down from the mountain peaks.

2074.text:
In thinking these things she fell asleep,
and it seemed at once that she was well again,

2080.text:
and that she was dressing for a walk. Clement
had called for her to climb the mountains

2086.text:
with him, and she was making preparation to
go, working swiftly and unhesitatingly—and

2093.text:
it seemed deliciously sweet to be swift and
active once more. She had put on a short walking-skirt

2101.text:
and leggins and was nearly ready. She stood
before the glass to put on her cap, and as

2108.text:
she saw how round and pink her cheeks were
she hardly recognized herself.

2115.text:
She seemed to hear his impatient feet outside
on the veranda, and she smiled to think how

2121.text:
typical it all was of husbands and wives—and
at that thought her face grew pinker and she

2128.text:
turned away—she didn't want her own eyes
to see how she flushed.

2134.text:
But suddenly all warmth—all flushing—left
her. She turned cold with a familiar creep

2141.text:
and weakness. She could not proceed. Her glove
was half on, but her strength was not sufficient

2149.text:
to pull it further. She could not lift her
feet.

2154.text:
His steady, strong tramp up and down the veranda
continued, but she was in the grasp of her

2160.text:
old enemy. A terrible fear and an agony of
desire seized her. She wanted to go out into

2168.text:
the bright sunlight with him, but she could
neither move nor whisper. All her resolution,

2176.text:
her hope, fell away, and her heart was heavy
and cold. It was all over. He would wait for

2184.text:
a while and then go away, and she would stand
there desolate, helpless, inert as clay, with

2192.text:
life dark and empty before her.
"Oh, if he would only call me!" was her last

2199.text:
breath of resolution.
Once, twice the feet went up and down the

2204.text:
veranda. Then they paused before her door.
"Are you ready?" his voice called.

2213.text:
She struggled to speak, but could only whisper,
"Yes."

2218.text:
The door swung quickly open and he stood there
in the streaming sunlight of the morning—so

2225.text:
tall he was he seemed to fill the doorway—and
he smiled and extended his hands.

2232.text:
"Come," he said, "the sturdy old mountains
are wonderfully grand this morning."

2239.text:
His hand closed over hers, and the sunlight
fell upon her, warming her to the heart, but

2246.text:
before she could lift her eyes to the shining
peaks she awoke and found that the morning

2252.text:
sun had stolen its way through a half-opened
shutter and lay upon her hand.

2258.text:
At first she was ready to weep with sadness
and despair, but as she thought upon it she

2264.text:
came to see in the dream a good omen. It had
been long since she had dreamed a vision of

2271.text:
perfect health with no touch of impotence
at its close. There was something of hope

2277.text:
in this vision; a man's hand had broken the
spell of weakness.

2288.text:
Days of witchery subtly sweet,
When every hill and tree finds heart,

2294.text:
When winter and spring like lovers meet
In the mist of noon and part—

2299.text:
In the April days.
Nights when the wood-frogs faintly peep—

2304.text:
Tr-eep, tr-eep—and then are still,
And the woodpeckers' martial voices sweep

2310.text:
Like bugle-blasts, from hill to hill,
Through the breathless haze.

2316.text:
Days when the soil is warm with rain,
And through the wood the shy wind steals,

2322.text:
Rich with the pine and the poplar smell,—
And the joyous soul like a dancer, reels

2334.text:
CHAPTER I
This dream gave to Clement, in Ellice's eyes,

2341.text:
a glamour of mystery and power—beyond the
subtlety of words, and she met him in a spirit

2347.text:
of awe and wonder, such as a child might feel
to find one of its dream-heroes actually beside

2354.text:
the fireside in the full sunlight of the morning.
The fear and agony and joy of the night's

2361.text:
vision gave a singular charm to the meeting.
It startled her to find she still retained

2368.text:
the capability of being moved by the sound
of a man's voice. It seemed like a wave of

2374.text:
returning life.
Her heart quickened as she saw him enter the

2379.text:
dining-room and look around for her—and
when his eyes fell upon her a light filled

2385.text:
his face which was akin to the morning. She
did not attempt to analyze the emotion thus

2392.text:
revealed, but she could not help seeing that
he looked the embodiment of health and happiness.

2399.text:
He wore a suit of light brown corduroy with
laced miner's boots, and they became him very

2406.text:
well.
He smiled down at her as he drew near.

2410.text:
"You are better this morning, I can see that."
It was exactly as if he knew of her dream,

2418.text:
and that the walk had been actual, and a flush
of pink crept into her face—so faint it

2424.text:
was no one noticed it—while it seemed to
her that her cheeks were scarlet. What magic

2430.text:
was this which made her flush—she whom Death
had claimed as his own?

2437.text:
Mr. Ross invited Clement to sit with them,
as she hoped he would. Clement had, indeed,

2443.text:
intended to force the invitation. "I'm going
for a gallop this morning," he said in explanation

2450.text:
of his dress. "I wish you could go too," he
added, addressing Ellice.

2457.text:
Mr. Ross introduced him to the elderly woman:
"Mr. Clement, let me present you to my sister,

2464.text:
Miss Ross."
Miss Ross was plump like her brother, and

2469.text:
a handsome woman, but irritable like him.
She complained, also, of the altitude and

2475.text:
of the chill shadows. Neither father nor aunt
formed a suitable companion for the sick girl.

2484.text:
Clement was the antidote. His whole manner
of treatment was of the hopeful, buoyant sort.

2491.text:
He spoke of the magnificent weather, of the
mountains, of the purity of the water.

2497.text:
"After I get back from my ride I wish you'd
let me come and talk with you. Perhaps," he

2503.text:
added, "you'll be able to walk a little way
with me."

2507.text:
He made the breakfast almost cheerful by his
presence, and went away saying:

2513.text:
"I'll be back by ten o'clock and I shall expect
to find you ready for a walk."

2519.text:
Miss Ross was astonished both at his assurance
and at Ellice's singular interest and apparent

2526.text:
acquiescence.
"Well, that is a most extraordinary man. I

2533.text:
wonder if that's the Western way."
"I wish I were able to do as he says," the

2539.text:
girl said quietly. The old people looked up
in astonishment.

2545.text:
"Aunt Sarah, I want you to help me dress.
I'm going to try to walk a little."

2551.text:
"Not with that man?" the aunt inquired in
protest.

2556.text:
"Yes, Aunt." Her voice was vibrant with fixed
purpose.

2562.text:
"But think how you would look leaning on his
arm."

2566.text:
"Auntie, dear, I have gone long past that
point. It doesn't matter how it looks. I cannot

2573.text:
live merely to please the world. He has asked
me, and if I can I will go."

2580.text:
Mr. Ross broke in, "Why, of course, what harm
can it do? I'd let her lean on the arm of

2588.text:
'Cherokee Bill' if she wanted to." They all
smiled at this, and he added, "The trouble

2595.text:
has been she didn't want to do anything at
all, and now she shall do what she likes."

2602.text:
It all seemed very coarse and common now,
and she could not tell them the secret of

2607.text:
the dream that had so impressed her, and of
her growing faith that this strong man could

2613.text:
help her back to health and life. She only
smiled in her slow, faint way, and made preparation

2621.text:
to go with him who meant so much to her.
He met her on the veranda in a handsome Prince

2627.text:
Albert suit of gray with a broad-brimmed gray
hat to match. He looked like some of the pictures

2635.text:
of Western Congressmen she had seen, only
more refined and gentle. He wore his coat

2643.text:
unbuttoned, and it had the effect of draping
his tall, erect frame, and the hat suited

2649.text:
well with the large lines of his nose and
chin. It seemed to her she had never seen

2656.text:
a more striking and picturesque figure.
"I'll carry you down the stairs if you'll

2662.text:
say the word," he said as they paused a moment
at the topmost step.

2667.text:
"Oh, no. I can walk if you will give me time."
"Time! Time is money. I can't afford it."

2677.text:
He stooped and lifted her in his right arm,
and before she could protest he was half way

2683.text:
down the stairway. He laughed at the horrified
face of the aunt. He was following impulses

2690.text:
now. As they walked side by side slowly—she,
not without considerable effort—up toward

2698.text:
the spring, he said abruptly, but tenderly:
"You must think you're better—that's half

2705.text:
the battle. See that stream? Some day I'm
going to show you where it starts. Do you

2712.text:
know if you drink of that water up at its
source above timber-line it will cure you?"

2720.text:
She saw his intent and said, "I'm afraid I'll
be cured before I get to the spring."

2726.text:
"I'm going to make it my aim in life to see
you drink at that pool." His directness and

2733.text:
simplicity stimulated her like some mediæval
elixir. He made her forget her pain. They

2742.text:
did not talk much until they were seated on
one of the benches near the fountain.

2747.text:
"Sit in the sun," he commanded. "Don't be
afraid of the sun. You hear people talk about

2754.text:
the sun's rays breeding disease. The sun never
does that. It gives life. Beware of the shadow,"

2763.text:
he added, and she knew he meant her mental
indifference. They had a long talk on the

2770.text:
bench. He told her of his family, of himself.
"You see," he said, "father had only a small

2779.text:
business, though he managed to educate me,
and, later, my brother. But when he died it

2786.text:
had less value, for I couldn't hold the trade
he had and times were harder. I kept brother

2793.text:
at college during his last two years, and
when he came out I gave the business to him

2799.text:
and got out. He was about to marry, and the
business wouldn't support us both. I was always

2807.text:
inclined to adventure anyway. Gold Creek was
in everybody's mouth, so I came here.

2815.text:
"Oh, that was a wonderful time; the walk across
the mountains was like a story to me. I liked

2822.text:
the newness of everything in the camp. It
was glorious to hear the hammers ringing,

2828.text:
and see the new pine buildings going up—and
the tent and shanties. It was rough here then,

2836.text:
but I had little to do with that. I staked
out my claim and went to digging. I knew very

2843.text:
little about mining, but they were striking
it all around me, and so I kept on. Besides"—here

2852.text:
he looked at her in a curiously shy way—"I've
always had a superstition that just when things

2858.text:
were worst with me they were soonest to turn
to the best, so I dug away. My tunnel went

2866.text:
into the hill on a slight upraise, and I could
do the work alone. You see I had so little

2872.text:
money I didn't want to waste a cent.
"But it all went at last for powder and the

2879.text:
sharpening of picks, and for assaying—till
one morning in August I found myself without

2886.text:
money and without food."
He paused there, and his face grew dark with

2892.text:
remembered despair, and she shuddered.
"It must be terrible to be without food and

2898.text:
money."
"No one knows what it means till he experiences

2903.text:
it. I worked all day without food. It seemed
as if I must strike it then. Besides, I took

2911.text:
a sort of morbid pleasure in abusing myself—as
if I were to blame. I had been living on canned

2920.text:
beans, and flapjacks, and coffee without milk
or sugar, and I was weak and sick—but it

2927.text:
all had to end. About four o'clock I dropped
my pick and staggered out to the light. It

2934.text:
was impossible to do anything more."
There were tears in her eyes now, for his

2941.text:
voice unconsciously took on the anguish of
that despair.

2945.text:
"I sat there looking out toward the mountains
and down on the camp. The blasts were booming

2952.text:
from all hills—the men were going home with
their dinner-pails flashing red in the setting

2958.text:
sun's light. It was terrible to think of them
going home to supper. It seemed impossible

2965.text:
that I should be sitting there starving, and
the grass so green, the sunset so beautiful.

2972.text:
I can see it all now as it looked then, the
old Sangre de Christo range! It was like a

2979.text:
wall of glistening marble that night.
"Well, I sat there till my hunger gnawed me

2986.text:
into action. Then I staggered down the trail.
I saw how foolish I had been to go on day

2994.text:
after day hoping, hoping until the last cent
was gone. I hadn't money enough to pay the

3001.text:
extra postage on a letter which was at the
office. The clerk gave me the letter and paid

3007.text:
the shortage himself. The letter was from
my sister, telling me how peaceful and plentiful

3014.text:
life was at home, and it made me crazy. She
asked me how many nuggets I had found. You

3021.text:
can judge how that hurt me. I reeled down
the street, for I must eat or die, I knew

3029.text:
that."
"Oh, how horrible!" the girl said softly.

3035.text:
"There was one eating-house at which I always
took my supper. It was kept by an Irish woman,

3043.text:
a big, hearty woman whose husband was a prospector—or
had been. 'Biddy Kelly's' was famous for its

3051.text:
'home cooking.' I went by the door twice,
for I couldn't bring myself to go in and ask

3058.text:
for a meal. You don't know how hard that is—it's
very queer, if a man has money he can ask

3065.text:
for credit or a meal, but if he is broke he'll
starve first. I could see Biddy waiting on

3073.text:
the tables—the smell that came out was the
most delicious, yet tantalizing, odor of beef-stew—it

3082.text:
made me faint with hunger."
His voice grew weak and his throat dry as

3088.text:
he spoke.
"When I did enter, Dan looked up and said

3092.text:
respectfully, 'Good-evenin', Mr. Clement,'
and I felt so ashamed of my errand I turned

3099.text:
to run. Everything whirled then—and when
I got my bearings again Dan had me on one

3107.text:
arm and Biddy was holding a bowl of soup to
my lips."

3112.text:
The girl sighed. "Oh, she was good, wasn't
she?"

3117.text:
"They fed me, for they could see I was starving,
and I told them about the mine—and, well,

3125.text:
some way I got them to 'grub-stake' me that
night."

3129.text:
"What is that?"
"That is, they agreed to furnish me food and

3134.text:
money for tools and share in profits. Dan
went to work with me, and do you know, it

3141.text:
ended in ruining them both. We organized a
company called the 'Biddy Mining Company.'

3148.text:
I was president, and Dan was vice-president,
and Biddy was treasurer. Biddy kept us going

3155.text:
by her eating-house, but eventually we wanted
machinery, and we mortgaged the eating-house,

3162.text:
and the money went into that hole in the ground.
But I knew we would succeed. I could hear

3169.text:
voices call me, 'Come, come!'—whenever I
was alone I could hear them plainly."

3177.text:
His eyes, turned upon her, were full of mystery.
"I have always felt the stir of life around

3184.text:
me in the dark, and there in that mine—after
we struck the spring of water—I thought

3191.text:
I heard voices all the time in the plash of
the water. I suppose it seemed like insanity,

3198.text:
for I ruined Dan and Biddy without mercy.
I couldn't stop. I was sure if we could only

3205.text:
hold out a little while we would reach it.
But we didn't. Biddy had to go to work as

3213.text:
a cook, and Dan and I went out to try to borrow
some money. I couldn't bear to let in somebody

3220.text:
else after all the heat and toil Dan and Biddy
and I had endured, but it had to be done.

3228.text:
We took in a fellow from Iowa by the name
of Eldred and went to work again.

3233.text:
"One day after our blast I was the first to
enter, and the moment that I saw the heap

3240.text:
of rock I knew we had opened the vein. My
wildest dreams were realized!"

3247.text:
"And then your troubles ended," the girl said
tenderly.

3253.text:
"No—for now a strange thing happened. The
assayer tried our ore again and again and

3261.text:
found it very rich, but when we shipped to
the mills we got almost no returns. We tried

3269.text:
every process, but the gold seemed to slip
away from us. Finally I took a carload and

3276.text:
went with it to see what was the matter. I
followed it till it came out on the plates—that

3281.text:
is where they catch the gold by the use of
quicksilver spread on copper plates—and

3287.text:
it seemed all right. I scraped some of it
up and put it into a small vial to take home

3293.text:
with me. When I got home the company assembled
to hear my report, and when I took out the

3300.text:
amalgam to show it to them it had turned to
a queer yellow-green liquid. I was astounded,

3308.text:
but Dan and Biddy crossed themselves. 'It's
witch's gold,' Biddy said. 'Dan, have no more

3316.text:
to do with it.' And witch's gold it was. They
gave up right there and went back to work

3324.text:
in the camp. Eldred cursed me for getting
him into it, and so they left me to fight

3331.text:
it out alone. I was like a monomaniac—I
never thought of giving up. I begged a little

3339.text:
money from my brother and bought in all the
stock of the 'Biddy Mining Company,' and went

3345.text:
to work to solve the mystery of the amalgam.
I was a good pupil in chemistry at college,

3352.text:
and I put my whole life and brain into that
mystery and I solved it. I found a way to

3358.text:
treat it so all the gold was saved. That made
me rich. I called the mine 'The Witch,' and

3367.text:
it has made me what you see."
"It is like a fairy tale! What became of your

3373.text:
faithful friends, Dan and Biddy?"
"I made Dan my foreman of the mine, and I

3380.text:
built an eating-house and hotel for Biddy.
They are with me yet. Eldred I bought out

3386.text:
on the same terms as the rest."
He had a sudden sensation of heat in his face

3393.text:
as he passed the chasm between the withdrawal
of Dan and Biddy from the firm and his solution

3399.text:
of the amalgam. He did not care to dwell upon
that, because Eldred had sued him to recover

3406.text:
his stock, claiming that it was bought in
under false pretenses. Neither did he care

3413.text:
to enter into the stormy time which followed
the sudden leap of "The Witch" from a haunted

3418.text:
hole in the ground to a cave of diamonds.
He hurried on to the end while she listened

3424.text:
in absorbed interest like a child to a wonder
story.

3430.text:
She sighed in the world-old manner of women
and said:

3434.text:
"And I—I have done nothing worth telling.
I ruined my health by careless living at school,

3441.text:
and here I am, a cumberer of the earth."
Some men would have hastened to be complimentary,

3449.text:
but Clement remained silent. He was trying
to understand her mood that he might meet

3455.text:
it in a helpful way.
"But if I am permitted to live I shall be

3460.text:
different. I will do something."
"First of all, get well," he said, and his

3467.text:
words had the force of a command. "Give me
your hand."

3473.text:
She complied, and he took it in a firm clasp.
"Now I want you to promise me you'll turn

3480.text:
your mind from darkness to the light, from
the cañons to the peaks—that you will determine

3487.text:
to live. Do you promise?"
"I promise."

3492.text:
"Very well. I shall see that you keep that
promise."

3497.text:
CHAPTER II
It was rather curious to see that as she grew

3502.text:
in strength Clement lost in assertiveness—in
his feeling of command. He began to comprehend

3510.text:
that with returning health the girl was not
altogether pitiable. She had culture, social

3516.text:
position and wealth.
The distinction of his readily-acquired millions

3522.text:
grew to be a very poor possession in his own
mind—in fact, he came at last to such self-confessed

3529.text:
utter poverty of mind and body that he wondered
at her continued toleration. He ceased to

3536.text:
plead any special worthiness on his own part
and began to throw himself on her mercy.

3543.text:
As the time came on when she no longer needed
his arm for support he found it hard to offer

3550.text:
it as an act of gallantry. In fact, in that
small act was typified the change which he

3557.text:
came ultimately to assume. At first she had
seemed to him like an angelic child. Death's

3564.text:
shadows had made him bold—but now he could
not deceive himself: he was coming to love

3570.text:
her in a very human and definite fashion.
He dared not refer to the past in any way,

3577.text:
and his visits grew more and more formal and
carefully accounted for.

3583.text:
She thought she understood all this, and was
serenely untroubled by it. She brooded over

3589.text:
the problem with dreamful lips and half-shut
eyes. She was drifting back to life on a current

3596.text:
of mountain air companioned by splendid clouds,
and her content was like to the lotus-eater's

3603.text:
languor—it held no thought of time or tide.
That she idealized him was true, but he grew

3611.text:
richly in grace. All the small amenities of
conduct which he once possessed came back

3618.text:
to him. He studied to please her, and succeeded
in that as in his other ventures. He did not

3626.text:
exactly abandon his business, but he came
to superintend his superintendents.

3632.text:
However, he attached a telephone to his mine
in order to be able to direct his business

3638.text:
from the Springs. He still roomed at the hotel,
though Ellice was living in a private house

3645.text:
farther up the cañon. His rooms were becoming
filled with books and magazines, and he was

3651.text:
struggling hard to "catch up" with the latest
literature.

3656.text:
If Ellice referred to any book, even in the
most casual way, he made mental note of it,

3663.text:
and if he had read it he re-read it, and if
he had not read it he secured it at once.

3669.text:
"I know something of chemistry and mineralogy,
and geology and milling processes, but of

3676.text:
art and literature very little," he said to
her once. "But give me time."

3683.text:
The highest peaks were white with September
snows before she felt able to mount a horse.

3690.text:
Each day she had been able to go a little
farther and climb a little higher. Her gain

3696.text:
was slow, very slow, but it was almost perceptible
from day to day.

3703.text:
Mr. Ross had been to Chicago, and was once
more at the Springs. He had brought a couple

3709.text:
of nieces, very lively young creatures, who
annoyed Clement exceedingly by their impertinence—at

3716.text:
least, that is what he called their excessive
interest in his affairs. Without the co-operation

3723.text:
of Ellice he would have found little chance
to see her alone, but she had a quiet way

3729.text:
of letting them know when she found them a
burden, which they respected.

3735.text:
One day he said to her, "Have you forgotten
what I said to you about the spring up there?"

3741.text:
"No, I have not forgotten. Do you think I
can go now? Am I really well enough to go?"

3749.text:
"The time has come."
"What would the doctor say?"

3756.text:
"The doctor—do you still heed what he says?"
"Must I walk?"

3761.text:
"Yes, to have the water heal you. But I will
lead old Wisconse for you to ride down."

3769.text:
"After I am healed?"
"One can be cured and yet be tired."

3776.text:
They set off in such spirits as children have,
old Wisconse leading soberly behind.

3784.text:
Clement was obliged to check the girl.
"Now don't go too fast. It is a long way up

3790.text:
there. I warn you it is almost at timber-line."
But she paid small heed to his warning. She

3799.text:
felt so light, so active, it seemed she could
not tire.

3804.text:
For a time they followed the wide road which
climbed steadily, but at last he stopped.

3810.text:
"Now here we strike the trail," he said. "You
must go ahead, for I am to lead the horse."

3817.text:
"Not far ahead," she exclaimed, a little bit
alarmed.

3823.text:
"Only two steps." He was a little amused at
her. "Just so I will not tread on your heels."

3831.text:
"You needn't laugh. I know they hunt bears
up here."

3838.text:
They climbed for some time in comparative
silence.

3842.text:
"Oh, how much greener it is up here!" she
exclaimed at last, looking around, her eyes

3849.text:
bright with excitement.
He smiled indulgently. "You tourists think

3855.text:
you know Colorado when you've crossed it once
on the railway. This is the Colorado which

3861.text:
you seldom see."
She was in rapture over the glory of color,

3867.text:
the waving grasses of smooth hillsides, and
the radiant dapple of light and shadow beneath

3873.text:
the groves of vivid yellow aspens. The cactus
and Spanish dagger, and the ever-present sage

3880.text:
bush of the lower levels, had disappeared,
crow's-foot and blue-joint grasses swung in

3886.text:
the wind. The bright flame of the painted
cup and the purple of the asters still lighted

3893.text:
up the aisles of the pines in sheltered places.
"There are many more in August," he explained.

3901.text:
"The frost has swept them all away."
"Is this our stream?" she asked.

3907.text:
"Yes, we cross it many times."
"How small it is."

3919.text:
He came close to her to listen to her breathing.
"You must not do too much. If you find yourself

3926.text:
out of breath stop and ride."
"I want to be cured."

3931.text:
He laughed. "By the way you lead up this trail
I don't think you need medicine. I never finish

3940.text:
wondering whether you are the same girl I
met first——"

3944.text:
She flashed a glance back at him. "I'm not.
I'm another person."

3950.text:
"That shows what three months of this climate
will do."

3961.text:
"You did." She kept marching steadily forward,
her head held very straight indeed.

3968.text:
"I wish you would wait a moment," he pleaded.
"I am very thirsty—I want to reach the spring."

3977.text:
"But, dear girl, you can't keep this up."
"Can't I? Watch me and see."

3986.text:
She seemed possessed of some miraculous staff,
for she mounted the steep trail as lightly

3992.text:
as a fawn. Clement was in an agony of apprehension
lest she should overdo and fall fainting in

3999.text:
the path. This ecstasy of activity was most
dangerously persistent.

4006.text:
It was past noon when they came out of the
aspens and pines into the little smooth slope

4012.text:
of meadow which lay between the low peaks
which were already crusted with snow. In the

4019.text:
midst of the orange and purple and red of
the grasses lay a deep, dark pool of water—as

4026.text:
beautiful as her eyes, it seemed to him.
"Here is the spring," Clement called to the

4037.text:
"Wait," he called again. "I must drink with
you."

4042.text:
He hastened up and dipped a cup into the water
and handed it to her.

4047.text:
"Now drink confusion to disease."
"Confusion!" She drank. "Oh, isn't it sweet?

4056.text:
I never knew before how good water was. But
here, drink. You are dying of thirst, too."

4064.text:
She handed him the cup.
"I want to drink to some purpose also," he

4069.text:
said, and there was no need of further words,
but he went on, his full heart giving eloquence

4076.text:
to his lips, "I want to pledge my life to
your service—my life and all I am."

4085.text:
She grew a little pale. This intensity of
emotion awed her as the majestic in Nature

4091.text:
affects great souls. "I don't think you ought.
I don't think I am quite worthy."

4099.text:
"Let me be judge of that." He spoke quickly
and almost sharply. "Shall I drink?"

4109.text:
She had walked on while Clement was speaking,
and stood leaning against the browsing horse.

4115.text:
After a little hesitation she answered, "If
you are thirsty."

4120.text:
She stood leaning against the browsing horse.
The words were light, but he understood her.

4125.text:
He drank and then came straight toward her.
She shrank from him in sudden timidity and

4132.text:
said a little hurriedly, "Help me into the
saddle. I shall need to ride back."

4144.text:
The half-sunk sun
Burns through the dusty-crimson sky;

4149.text:
Streamers of gold and green soar
In radiating splendor, like the spokes

4154.text:
Of God's unmeasurable chariot-wheels
Half-hid and vanishing.

4160.text:
Around me is coolness, ripeness and repose;
The smell of gathered grain and fruits,

4167.text:
And the musky breath of melons fills the air.
The very dust is fruity, and the click

4173.text:
Of locusts' wings is like the close
Of gates upon great stores of wheat.

4179.text:
The gathered barley bleaches in shock,
The corn breathes on me from the west,

4185.text:
And the sky-line widens on and on
Until I see the waves of yellow-green

4191.text:
Break on the hills that face the snow and
lilac peaks

4201.text:
At first Clement's happiness had no further
base of uneasiness than the lover's fear of

4207.text:
loss. It all seemed too good to be true, and
he had a hidden fear that something might

4213.text:
happen to set him back where he was before
she came. It was quite like his feeling about

4220.text:
his mine—it took him a certain length of
time before he ceased to dream of its sudden

4225.text:
loss, and now it seemed (when absent from
her) that it would be easy for something to

4231.text:
rob him of this love which was his life.
This feeling was mixed, too, with a feeling

4238.text:
of his unworthiness, which deepened the more
closely he studied her. She was so free from

4245.text:
all bruise and stain of life's battle. There
were no questionable places in her life. Could

4253.text:
he say as much?
Whenever he asked himself the question his

4258.text:
dealings with the stockholders of "The Biddy"
came into his mind. Could he afford to tell

4264.text:
his bride all the facts in the case? This
feeling of dissatisfaction with himself led

4271.text:
him to do many extravagant things. He presented
her with beautiful and costly jewels for which

4278.text:
she had little taste.
"Why, Richard. What made you think of that?"

4284.text:
she said once after he had slipped away to
the city to buy her something.

4290.text:
"Is it so very pretty?"
"It is beautiful! But can we afford such things?"

4297.text:
"We can afford anything that will make you
happy."

4302.text:
He made a similar answer when she drew back
a little startled at the cost of the house

4308.text:
he had contracted for.
"Why, it is a palace!"

4313.text:
"The best is scarcely good enough for you."
After a moment he added, "You see, I know

4322.text:
you can never live East again, and I want
you to have all the comforts of a palace out

4327.text:
here. And so long as 'The Witch' holds out
you shall have your heart's desire."

4335.text:
Mr. Ross had come to have a profound respect
for his future son-in-law. "I can't say that

4342.text:
he don't make as much of a fool of himself
as any prospective bridegroom, but he is a

4347.text:
business man at the same time. He don't lose
his head, by any means." He was telling his

4355.text:
son about Clement. "He is devoted to your
sister, but I went over to his mine with him

4362.text:
the other day and it is perfectly certain
that he understands his business. He is only

4368.text:
reckless when buying things for Ellice. He'll
take care of her and the mine, too."

4376.text:
Clement felt a certain incongruity every time
he put on his miner's dress and went through

4381.text:
the mine. "I'm too rough for her, too old,"
he kept thinking—trying to conceal the real

4389.text:
cause of his growing fear.
He was not honest with himself. He fought

4395.text:
round the real point of danger. He gave a
generous sum to the library, aided a hospital,

4403.text:
and did other things which should ease a bad
conscience, and yet do not. He hastened the

4410.text:
house forward, and passed to and fro between
his mine, the Springs and the city in ceaseless

4418.text:
activity.
The marriage was set for July, just a year

4423.text:
from the time he first saw her, and the winter
passed quickly, so busied was he in building

4429.text:
and planning the home. He grew less and less
buoyant and more careworn as spring wore on,

4437.text:
and Ellice could not understand the change.
He was moody and changeable even in her presence.

4445.text:
This troubled her, and she often asked:
"What is the matter, Richard? Is your business

4452.text:
going wrong?"
"No, oh no. Business is all right. Nothing

4458.text:
is the matter." And ended by convincing her
that something was very much wrong indeed.

4466.text:
And she grieved in silence, not daring to
question him further.

4472.text:
The self-revealing touch came to him in a
curious way only a few days before their wedding

4478.text:
day. He was in camp on a final inspection
of his mine, and was walking the streets at

4485.text:
night, silent, self-absorbed and gloomy. He
had grown morbid and unwholesome in his thought,

4494.text:
and the wreck of his happiness seemed already
complete. He spent a great deal of time in

4500.text:
long and lonely walks.
The street swarmed with rough, noisy miners.

4507.text:
A band of evangelists, with drums and tambourines,
occupied the central corner. A low, continuous

4516.text:
hum of talk could be heard at the base of
all other noises.

4521.text:
Being in no mood for companionship Clement
stood aside from it all, thinking how far

4527.text:
above all this life his beautiful bride was.
There had been in the camp for some weeks

4534.text:
a certain sensational evangelist—a man of
some power, but of unhappy disposition apparently.

4543.text:
At any rate he had been in much trouble with
the city authorities. He had been called a

4549.text:
"hypocrite and fake" in the public press,
and had been prosecuted for disturbance of

4555.text:
the peace. But he seemed to thrive on such
treatment.

4561.text:
Clement had paid very little attention to
the man and his troubles, but as he looked

4565.text:
down the street at the crowd around the speakers
on the corner it occurred to him to wonder

4570.text:
if they were the fighting evangelists.
He was about to move that way when he observed

4576.text:
near him in the dark middle of the street
a man and a woman.

4581.text:
"This will do as well as anywhere," the man
said, putting down a small box. He wore a

4588.text:
broad cowboy hat, and a long coat which hung
unbuttoned down his powerful figure. The woman

4596.text:
was tall and slender, and neatly dressed in
gray. Clement understood that these were the

4603.text:
persecuted ones.
The man mounted the box, and in a powerful

4609.text:
but not very musical voice began to sing a
hymn full of cowboy slang. His singing had

4616.text:
a quality not usual in street singers, and
a crowd quickly gathered about him. His song

4624.text:
was long and not without a rude poetry. He
began his address at last by issuing a defiance

4631.text:
to his enemies. This would mean little in
an Eastern village, perhaps, but in a mining

4638.text:
camp, even a degenerate mining camp, it might
mean a great deal—life or death, in fact.

4647.text:
"Now, gentlemen, I want to say something as
a preface in order to know just where we stand.

4653.text:
Some citizens of the town have vilified me
in private and in the public press—over

4659.text:
an assumed name, however. It wouldn't be healthy
for any man to do it openly. The man is a

4667.text:
liar—but I don't care about myself. It is
a little difference of opinion among men,

4673.text:
but some miscreant has reflected upon the
good name of my wife. Now let me say that

4680.text:
the man that says my wife is not a lady and
a woman of the highest character, insults

4686.text:
the mother of my children and will answer
to me for every word he utters."

4692.text:
A little thrill of interest and awe ran through
the crowd. The man's voice meant battle, and

4700.text:
battle to the hilt of the bowie. It was so
easy to prove a mark for desperate men, but

4707.text:
there was no fear in the attitude of the speaker.
He had come up through a wild life, and knew

4713.text:
his audience, his accuser and himself.
His voice took a sudden change—it grew tender

4721.text:
and reverent. "I am here to preach the gospel
of Christ and Him crucified. I may not do

4730.text:
it in the best way always, but I do it as
well as I know how." Here his tone grew severely

4738.text:
earnest and savage again, as he added: "But
I shall defend the honor of my wife with my

4745.text:
life."
His voice and pose were magnificent—lion-like.

4752.text:
His manner changed again with dramatic suddenness.
He took the whole street into his confidence.

4760.text:
"I love my wife, gentlemen. She has borne
three children to me. She is a good woman.

4767.text:
A mighty sight smarter and better than I am,
but she can't defend herself against sneaks

4773.text:
and reptilious liars. I can. That's part of
my business. I tell you, boys," he added in

4782.text:
a low voice very sincere and winning, "they
ain't no man good enough to marry a good woman;

4789.text:
it's just her good, pure, kind heart gives
him any show at all."

4795.text:
A sudden lump rose in Clement's throat. The
man's deep humility and loyalty and apparent

4802.text:
sincerity had gone straight to his own heart
and touched him in a very sensitive place.

4810.text:
He turned away and sought the deeper shadow
with his head bowed in black despair.

4816.text:
He thought of the eyes of his bride with a
shudder almost of fear. Could he ever face

4822.text:
her again?
"Oh, God! How pure and dainty and unspotted

4829.text:
she is, and I—I am unclean."
He saw as clearly as if a light had been turned

4837.text:
in upon his secret thought, that the ownership
of "The Witch" was in question. He had not

4844.text:
been candid with her—he had been dishonest.
He had not dared to let her know how he had

4851.text:
secured control of that stock.
All the way back to the Springs he wrestled

4857.text:
with himself about it. He ended by reasserting
the justice of his position, and resolved

4864.text:
to tell her at once the whole story and let
her judge. He had in his pocket the deed to

4871.text:
the house and lot, which he determined now
to give her at once, and to make explanations

4878.text:
at the same time.
This he did. He called to see her the following

4883.text:
afternoon and found her surrounded with women
and gowns and flowers. The women fled when

4891.text:
he approached, but the gowns and flowers remained,
and there was talk upon them till at last,

4898.text:
in sheer desperation, Clement said:
"Ellice, here is something that I want to

4904.text:
give you now. It is my wedding gift."
He placed in her hand the deed. She looked

4912.text:
at it.
"Oh, there's so much fine print. I can't read

4917.text:
it now. What is it?"
"It is the deed to the new home."

4924.text:
Her eyes misted with quick emotion.
"How good you are to me, Richard."

4931.text:
"No, it's precaution," he replied as lightly
as he could. "We will have a home always if

4939.text:
you don't lose it in some wild speculation."
She put her arms about his neck, an infrequent

4946.text:
caress with her.
"How rich we are. God is good to us. And is

4952.text:
it not good to think that our wealth does
not come from anybody's misery? It comes out

4957.text:
of the earth like a spring—like the spring
that made me well."

4964.text:
As he looked down into her face it seemed
lit from within by some Heavenly light, and

4970.text:
her voice made his head grow dizzy. He could
not tell her his story then.

4977.text:
He sat down and listened to her talk. She
wanted to know what troubled him, and he was

4984.text:
forced to lie.
"Oh, nothing. I'm a little worried about a—new

4991.text:
piece of machinery." This gave him a thought.
"I must be away this evening. I can't take

4999.text:
dinner with you."
She was not one of those who worry with expostulations

5004.text:
or complainings. She had a mind of her own,
and she granted the same decision to others.

5011.text:
"Very well," she said, and she flashed a sudden
roguish look at him. "Don't forget to breakfast

5020.text:
with me."
He had the grace to return her smile as he

5025.text:
said:
"Oh, I'll not forget. I've charged my mind

5030.text:
with it."
His going was like a flight. His inner cry

5035.text:
was this:
"My God! I am absolutely unworthy of her.

5042.text:
I am big, coarse and dishonest—unfit to
touch her hand."

5049.text:
His gloomy face and bent head was a subject
of joke for the acquaintances he met on the

5055.text:
street.
"Saddle Susanna," he called sharply to his

5059.text:
Mexican hostler. He had made up his mind to
radical measures.

5066.text:
As he sat in his room with his face buried
in his hands shutting out the light of the

5071.text:
splendid sunset, he saw her as she sat among
her soft silks and dainty flowers. Her lovely

5079.text:
eyes and the exquisite texture of her skin
grew more and more wonderful to him. The touch

5086.text:
of his lips to hers came to seem an act of
pollution, almost of envenoming, as he brooded

5093.text:
on his unworthiness.
He wrote a note to her on the impulse of the

5099.text:
moment. The missive read:
"I am not fit to see you, to touch you. I

5106.text:
am going away across the divide to make restitution
for a great wrong I have done. If I do not

5113.text:
I can never face you again. When I see you
again I will be an honest man, or I—if you

5122.text:
think me worthy of forgiveness I will see
you and ask it to-morrow.

5128.text:
Richard."
He added as a postscript:

5131.text:
"I am well. I am not crazy, but I am not an
honest man. I can't kiss you again till I

5140.text:
am."
Upon reading this note he saw it would frighten

5146.text:
her, and keep her in agony of suspense, therefore
he tore it up, and rushing out of the house

5153.text:
leaped into the saddle.
The spirited little broncho was fresh and

5159.text:
mettlesome, and went off in a series of sheeplike
bounds which her rider seemed not to notice.

5167.text:
He drew rein at the telegraph office, and
there sent three telegrams. They were all

5174.text:
alike:
"Meet me at the office at midnight. Important."

5181.text:
As he turned Susanna's head up the trail the
mountains stood deep purple silhouettes against

5188.text:
the cloudlessness of the sky. The wind blew
from the heights cool and fragrant, and the

5194.text:
little horse set nostril to it as if she anticipated
and welcomed the hard ride.

5202.text:
The way lay over forbidding mountain passes
ten thousand feet above the sea, and her rider

5209.text:
was a heavy man. But Susanna was of broncho
strain with a blooded sire, which makes the

5217.text:
hardiest and swiftest mountain horse in the
world.

5221.text:
Clement's mind cleared as he began the ascent—cleared
but did not rest. Over and over the problem

5230.text:
came, each time clearer and more difficult.
He must that night give away a hundred and

5237.text:
thirty-five thousand dollars—terrible ordeal!
Ninety thousand dollars to go to an old Irishman

5246.text:
and his wife—both ignorant, careless.
What would they do with it? It might drive

5254.text:
them crazy. As they now lived they were comfortable.
He had made Dan sub-superintendent of the

5261.text:
mine, and he had rebuilt the eating-house
for Biddy. Could they take care of the big

5267.text:
fortune he was about to give them?
Ought he not to give them a few thousands—such

5273.text:
sum as they could comprehend and take care
of? Would it not be better for them?

5280.text:
Then there was forty-five thousand dollars
to be given to a cheap little man—that was

5287.text:
hardest of all, for he had come to hate the
sight of the sleek black head of Arthur Eldred.

5294.text:
Yes, but he had saved the day. He had put
in six hundred dollars when every dollar was

5300.text:
a ducat. True, but the reward was too great.
A hundred thousand dollars for six hundred.

5309.text:
Oh, this was familiar ground! He had gone
over it in a sort of sub-conscious way a hundred

5317.text:
times, each time apparently the final one.
It had been quite settled when this slender

5323.text:
little woman first lifted her face to him,
and now nothing was settled.

5330.text:
It was very still and cold. There was no stream
to sing up through the pines, and no wind

5337.text:
in the pines to answer should the stream call.
Nothing seemed to be stirring save the pensive

5344.text:
man and his faithful pony.
Reaching the upper levels he spurred on at

5350.text:
a gallop, finding some relief in the pounding
action of the saddle and in the rush of air

5356.text:
past his ears. The moon was late, but when
it came it seemed to help him, lightening

5364.text:
his mood as it lightened the trail. The big
ledges and lowering, lesser peaks lifted into

5372.text:
the dark sky weirdly translucent, and their
upper edges seemed smooth and graceful as

5379.text:
the rims of bubbles. Solid rock seemed melted
and transfused with light and air. It was

5388.text:
all miraculously beautiful, and the sore-hearted
man lifted his eyes to the heights seeing

5394.text:
the face of a girl in every moonlit rock and
in every wayside pool.

5401.text:
As he entered the office he found them all
waiting for him—Dan and Biddy in their best

5408.text:
dress, and Eldred with a supercilious half-grin,
half-scowl on his face.

5415.text:
Clement nodded at him, but said "Hello" to
Dan and "Good-evening" to Biddy. Conly, his

5424.text:
trusted, discreet cashier, was at his desk,
and the office was dimly lit with a single

5430.text:
electric bulb.
Dan and Biddy greeted him cautiously, for

5436.text:
Eldred had filled their simple souls with
suspicion. "He wants to compromise. He's afraid

5444.text:
of our suit against him."
As a matter of fact Dan would never put a

5450.text:
dollar into the plan for a suit, and it had
never gone beyond Eldred's talk—and yet

5457.text:
he had made them suspicious. Dan was forced
to confess that Clement was becoming an "a-ristocrat."

5465.text:
And Biddy acknowledged that he "sildom dairkened
her dure these days." They had always felt

5473.text:
his superiority and refinement, and they rose
as he entered.

5479.text:
He wasted no time in preliminaries. "Sit down,"
he said imperiously, and his face, when he

5486.text:
turned to the light, was knotted with trouble.
He sat for a moment with bent head while he

5493.text:
strengthened his heart to a bitter and humiliating
task. He began abruptly:

5500.text:
"Dan, you remember the time I brought the
amalgam home in a vial and it had turned green?"

5507.text:
"I do. Yis."
"You remember that you gave it up right then."

5514.text:
"I did. I said it's 'witch's gould.'"
"Sure such it looked like that day," said

5522.text:
Biddy.
"All the same, the thing which scared you

5527.text:
put a happy thought into my head, and I felt
then I could solve it." He lifted his head

5534.text:
and looked around defiantly. "In short, when
I bought your stock in at ten cents on the

5541.text:
dollar I knew it was worth par, for I had
solved the process."

5547.text:
There was a silence very awesome following
the defiant ring of the voice.

5554.text:
Eldred was the first to comprehend what it
meant. His eyes glittered like those of an

5559.text:
awakened rat.
"Do you mean that? If that's true you robbed

5566.text:
us, you thief, robbed us cold and clean."
He sprang up. "I knew you'd do something——"

5575.text:
"Sit down," interrupted Clement harshly. "I'm
not going to have any words with you. If I

5582.text:
had seen fit not to tell you of this how much
would you have known of it? Sit down and keep

5589.text:
your tongue between your teeth." He turned
to Dan and his voice was softer. "Dan, when

5597.text:
I was hungry you took me in and fed me. For
that I've given you a good position. Is that

5605.text:
debt paid?"
"Sure, Clement, me boy, it was only a sup

5613.text:
of p'taties an' bacon, annyway."
"Biddy, I turned over two thousand dollars

5618.text:
to you, and rebuilt your eating-house. You
thought that paid the debt I owed you?"

5626.text:
Biddy was slower to answer. "For all the grub
an' the loikes o' that, indade yis, Mr. Clement—but

5634.text:
sure we wor pardners——"
Clement interrupted. "I know. I'm coming to

5641.text:
that. Now answer me. If it hadn't been for
me wouldn't you have thrown up the sponge

5647.text:
long before you did?"
The silence of the little group answered him.

5653.text:
"Would any of you ever have worked out the
mystery of that ore? Weren't you all anxious

5660.text:
to sell for anything you could get?"
They were all silent as before.

5666.text:
"I made the mine worth money. I discovered
the secret, it was my invention. I paid you

5675.text:
four times what you had put into it. The mine
was worthless until I invented a process for

5681.text:
saving the gold. I claimed it as an invention
like any man claims a patent right. I believed

5689.text:
I had a right to it—to all of it, and so
I bought in your stock after I had solved

5695.text:
the problem of the reduction. I say I believed
I was right—to-night I believe I was wrong—it

5705.text:
don't matter how I came to the conclusion,
but I've changed my mind. I have come to-night

5712.text:
to make restitution. I am ready to pay you
ninety cents more on every dollar of stock

5719.text:
you sold me at that time."
Biddy gasped: "Howly Saints!"

5727.text:
Dan leaped up with a wild hurrah. "Listen
to that now!" he cried, with other incoherences.

5736.text:
He shook Clement's hand and kissed Biddy.
He praised Clement.

5742.text:
"Ye're the whitest man that iver stepped green
turf."

5748.text:
Clement sat coldly impassive and unsmiling.
"Then you're satisfied?"

5755.text:
"Satisfied!" shouted Dan. "Satisfied is it,
man? Indade I am."

5763.text:
"And you, Biddy?"
Biddy was weeping and muttering wild Irish

5769.text:
prayers. "Dan, dear, do ye understand, it's
forty-five thousand dollars apiece to the

5776.text:
two of us. Oh, the blessed old Ireland! I'll
go back sure. Oh, it's too good to be true—we

5786.text:
must be dramin'."
Clement looked at the distracted woman with

5791.text:
a flush of self-righteousness. He had been
right in his fears. It seemed like to ruin

5798.text:
the simple souls. He turned to Eldred, who
sat in silence.

5804.text:
"What have you to say?"
