Eldred sneered. "I say you can't fool me.

5813.text:
These shares are worth seventeen dollars and
eighty cents each. I want their market value,

5820.text:
not their par value. I want one-quarter the
present value of 'The Witch.'"

5827.text:
Clement's brow darkened and his eyes burned
with a fierce steady light.

5833.text:
"Is that all you want? If I served you right
I'd kick you out of the door and let you do

5840.text:
your worst. I know if you sue that you can't
recover one dollar from me. But I have my

5848.text:
reasons for putting up with your insolence.
I will pay you forty-five thousand dollars

5855.text:
and not one cent more. The market value of
'The Witch' to-day I have made by my management.

5863.text:
I have gone on improving the mine day by day.
As it stands it is a new property. You were

5871.text:
a quarter owner in 'The Biddy.' We capitalized
'The Biddy' at your own suggestion at two

5877.text:
hundred thousand dollars, because we wanted
it big enough to cover all values. When I

5884.text:
render you your share of that I am doing you
justice. John, make out three checks for forty-five

5892.text:
thousand dollars each."
Dan and Biddy turned upon Eldred and talked

5898.text:
him into silence, but he was unconvinced.
Clement refused to touch the checks, and the

5906.text:
clerk said: "Here is yours, Biddy."
Biddy went up and took the slip in her hands.

5913.text:
"Is that little slip o' white paper really
worth so much?"

5918.text:
"Call at the bank and get your money when
you want it," said the imperturbable cashier.

5925.text:
Dan studied his check, his face foolish with
joy.

5931.text:
Eldred took his, saying, "This puts into my
hands the means to fight."

5938.text:
Clement merely nodded. "You know my address."
Eldred went out without further word.

5947.text:
When the door closed on him Clement's face
lost its sternness, and he became sad and

5953.text:
tender.
His struggle was not yet done. His mind was

5958.text:
clear about the man who came in at the eleventh
hour, but it was not clear with regard to

5964.text:
these true-hearted old friends who had been
with him from the first. He recalled the time

5971.text:
when Dan's big arm had helped him to a chair,
and Biddy had put the steaming soup before

5977.text:
him—food worth all the gold in the world
at that moment. He recalled her broad, kindly

5985.text:
face, hot and shining from the stove; he remembered
their struggles, their sacrifices.

5992.text:
"Wait a moment, Biddy," he said, as they called
out "Good-night," and started to leave.

5999.text:
"Sit down a moment, and you, too, Dan. I want
to talk over old times a while."

6007.text:
They sat down in stupefaction.
"Biddy, do you remember the money you squandered

6013.text:
on the lottery ticket?"
A slow smile broadened her face. "I do, Mister

6021.text:
Clement—and I remember I won the prize sure!"
"You did, and saved all our lives. Dan, do

6030.text:
you remember the day we lost our last five-dollar
gold piece in the grass?"

6036.text:
Dan slapped his knee. "Do I? I wore me hands
raw as beef combin' the grass that day."

6045.text:
"Ah, those were great days. We had days when
forty-five cents would have made us joyous,

6053.text:
and here you are with ninety thousand dollars,
and wishin' for more."

6059.text:
Dan laughed again. "Sure, that's no lie."
"It is, Dan Kelly," said Biddy. "I have enough—too

6069.text:
much. My heart misgives me now. I'm afraid
of it, sure. I'm scared to carry it away wid

6076.text:
me."
"You're safe, Biddy; nobody will steal that

6081.text:
check." A sudden impulse seized him. "Dan,
you believed in me in those days—give me

6089.text:
that check." Dan slowly handed to him the
check. Clement took it and turned. "Biddy,

6099.text:
you fed me when I was starving, and you pawned
everything you had to 'grub-stake' me—give

6105.text:
me your check." She handed it to him without
hesitation. He tore them into small pieces.

6114.text:
"Dan, you are mining boss, and I make you
both quarter owners in 'The Witch' with all

6120.text:
I have, and share and share alike, as we did
when we hadn't a dime. Now hurrah for 'The

6129.text:
Witch.'"
Nobody shouted but the cashier. Dan sat in

6134.text:
a stupor, and Biddy was weeping, with one
arm flung around Dan's neck. Dan was turning

6142.text:
his hat around on his fingers and staring
at Clement's face for some solution to the

6148.text:
situation. It was beyond his imagination.
Clement did not speak again for some moments.

6157.text:
When he did his voice was husky and tremulous
with emotion. "You notice I say quarter interest—that's

6166.text:
because there is a new member in the firm
now. She comes in to-morrow. I want you to

6173.text:
see how she looks." He extended a picture
of Ellice to Biddy. She made a marvelous dramatic

6182.text:
shift of features, and a smile of admiration
broke through the red of her broad countenance.

6188.text:
"Oh, the swate, blessed angel. Sure, she's
beautiful as one of the saints in the church.

6195.text:
Luk at her, Dan."
"I'm lukin'. She's none too good for him."

6203.text:
"Don't say that, Dan!" Clement protested in
an earnest tone. "All you have to-night you

6211.text:
owe to her. All the best thoughts in me to-day
I owe to her."

6220.text:
There remained to him now all the joy of riding
back to tell her of his purification of soul.

6227.text:
His heart was so joyous it kept time to every
happy song in the world.

6233.text:
The gloom and doubt of himself had passed
away, but the wonder and mystery of woman's

6239.text:
love for man remained. He felt himself to
be an honest man, but a man big, crude and

6248.text:
coarse compared to her beauty and delicacy.
He marveled at her bravery and her magnanimity.

6257.text:
Leaving Susanna he leaped upon a fresh horse
and set off, riding fast toward the divide.

6264.text:
The wind had risen and was blowing from the
dim domes of the highest mountains—a cold

6270.text:
wind, and he would have said a sad wind had
his heart not been so light. As it was, he

6278.text:
lifted his bared forehead to it exultantly.
He put behind him, so far as in his power

6285.text:
lay, all thought of the great wealth he had
given away. He was eager to pour out the whole

6292.text:
story to her, and hear her say, "Well done,
Richard."

6298.text:
Over and over again his thought ran: "Now
I am an honest man. I am not worthy of her,

6305.text:
but at least my heart is clean."
Henceforth she was to be his altar of sacrifice.

6314.text:
All he did would be for her approval. All
there was of his money, his inventive skill,

6320.text:
his command of men, should be hers. She should
regulate every hour of his coming and going,

6328.text:
and share all the plans and purposes of his
life.

6332.text:
"Oh, I must live right, and deal justly,"
he thought. "I must be a better man from this

6339.text:
time forth."
In the east the pale lances of the coming

6344.text:
sun pierced the breasts of the soaring gray
clouds, and, behold, they grew to be the most

6351.text:
splendid orange and red and purple. The stars
began to pale, and as he came to the eastern

6359.text:
slope where the plain stretched to dim splendor,
like a motionless sea of russet and purple,

6367.text:
the sun was rising.
The plain seemed lonely and desolate of life,

6373.text:
so far below was it. All action was lost in
the mist of immensity—men's stature that

6381.text:
of the most minute insects. And down there
in the pathway of the morning was the little

6387.text:
woman of all the world waiting for him!
As he rode down the slope to the river level

6394.text:
into the town the sun was swinging, big and
red, high above the horizon. His long ride

6402.text:
had made him look wan and pale, but he ordered
coffee and a biscuit, and was glad to find

6409.text:
it helped him to look less wan and sorrowful.
He dressed with great care, then sat down

6416.text:
to wait. At 7:30 o'clock he sent a note to
her:

6422.text:
"I have not forgotten. When do you breakfast?"
She replied:

6428.text:
"Good-morning, dearest. Breakfast is ready;
come as soon as you can."

6434.text:
He entered the room with the heart of a boy,
the presence of an athlete. He was at his

6441.text:
prime of robust manhood, and his physical
pride was unconscious.

6447.text:
She was proud of him, and met him more than
half way in his greeting. Her face was still

6453.text:
slender and delicate of color, but in her
eyes was a serene brightness, and her lips

6460.text:
were tremulous with happiness.
She led him to the little table. "Now you

6467.text:
mustn't call this breakfast," she explained.
"This is a private cup of coffee to sustain

6474.text:
us through the ordeal. We all breakfast immediately
after the ceremony."

6479.text:
"I've had one breakfast this morning."
She looked dismayed.

6486.text:
"At least a roll and a cup of coffee," he
hastened to explain. "However, I think I could

6493.text:
eat all there is here and not be inconvenienced."
They sat down and looked at each other in

6501.text:
silence. She spoke first.
"Just think, this is the last time you will

6507.text:
ever sit down with Miss Ross."
"You seem to be sad about it."

6514.text:
"I am—and yet I am very happy. I don't suppose
you men can understand, but a woman wants

6522.text:
to marry the man she loves—and yet she is
sad at leaving girlhood behind. Now let me

6530.text:
see, you take two lumps, don't you? I must
not forget that. It makes the waiter stare

6537.text:
when a wife can't remember how many lumps
of sugar her husband takes."

6542.text:
He felt his courage oozing away, and so began
abruptly:

6547.text:
"Ellice, I have a story to tell and a confession
to make to you."

6554.text:
She looked a little startled. "That sounds
ominous, Richard—like the villain in the

6560.text:
play, only he makes his confession after marriage."
He was very sober indeed now. "That's the

6570.text:
reason I make mine now. I want you to know
just what I am before you marry me."

6577.text:
She leaned her chin on her clasped hands and
looked at him. "Tell me all about it."

6584.text:
He did. He began at the beginning, and while
it would not be true to say he did not spare

6590.text:
himself, he told the story as it actually
happened. He concealed no essential.

6598.text:
"I rode there and back last night simply because
I couldn't kiss you again until I had made

6604.text:
myself an honest man."
She reached out and clutched the hand which

6610.text:
lay on the table near her—a sudden convulsive
embrace.

6614.text:
"Last night?"
"Yes, I've been to the camp since I left you

6621.text:
last night. I couldn't stand with you—there—before
all our friends, till I could say I had no

6628.text:
other man's money in my pockets."
She took his hand in both of her own and bent

6635.text:
her head and touched her cheek to his fingers.
She was very deeply moved.

6641.text:
And he—though his voice choked—faltered
through:

6645.text:
"I gave it all back, dear—I mean I gave
over to Biddy and Dan their full share—they

6653.text:
are equal owners with you and me in 'The Witch.'
I tried to withhold some of it; it was hard

6660.text:
to give it all back; but I did it because
I believed you would approve of it. And now,

6667.text:
if you will let me, I can call you my wife
with a clear conscience."

6673.text:
For answer she rose and came to his side,
and put her arms about his neck and laid a

6679.text:
kiss on his upturned face. Words were of no
avail. In his heart the man was still afraid

6688.text:
of one so good and loving.
THE END

6694.text:
End of The Spirit of Sweetwater by Hamlin
Garland
